questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to an emergency with a history of chest pain, which is acute onset. The
ECG shows ST depression and T waves inversion. Cardiac biomarkers in the blood are not elevated.
What will be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Antiplatelets + LMW Heparin subcutaneous Explanation: This is a case
of acute coronary syndrome (unstable angina). During angina episodes, as well as during
asymptomatic ischemia, the characteristic ECG change is horizontal or downsloping ST-segment
depression that reverses after the ischemia disappears. T wave flattening or inversion may also
occur. Beta-blockers should be considered for first-line therapy in most patients with chronic angina.
Patients should receive a combination of antiplatelet and anticoagulant agents on presentation.

questions.text: A victim is found unconscious at the roadside. As a trained rescuer, after checking the victim's response and pulse, you decide on resuscitation. What is the recommended ratio of chest compression to ventilation during CPR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 30: 2 Explanation: For basic life support trained healthcare provider
should check for a pulse (taking no longer than 10 s) and assess breathing and start chest
compressions without delay and administered at a rate of 100-120/min depressing the sternum by 5
cm. ? For advanced life support, the initial priority is to assess the patient's cardiac rhythm by
attaching a defibrillator or monitor and start CPR at a rate of 30:2 by the resuscitation team. (For one
healthcare provider, the compression-ventilation ratio should be 30:2 for all age groups, and for two
2
rescuers; the compression-ventilation ratio should be 30:2 in adults and 15:2 in infants, children, and
adolescents (Ghai). Ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia should be treated with
immediate defibrillation by a biphasic shock defibrillator. Defibrillation is usually administered using a
150-joule biphasic shock, and CPR resumed immediately for 2 minutes without confirming the
restoration of a pulse because restoration cardiac output rarely occurs immediately after
defibrillation, biphasic shocks of 150-200 joules should be given every 2 minutes after each cycle of
CPR. Pulseless electrical activity should be treated by continuing CPR and adrenaline and looking for
the cause. Asystole should be treated similarly, with the additional support of atropine and
sometimes external or transvenous pacing to generate electrical rhythm. After the restoration of
normal rhythm, the ABCDE approach, aiming for Sp02 of 94-99%, aim for normal PaCO2, 12-lead
ECG, to treat the precipitating cause, and management target temperature should be done. ? During
CPR following should be ensured: high-quality chest compressions, minimizing interruptions to
compressions, providing oxygen, use of waveform capnography, performing continuous compressions
when advanced airway in place, IV cannulation (intravenous or interosseous), giving adrenaline every
3-5 min, give amiodarone after 3 shocks ? Reversible causes are (4H) ie. Hypoxia, Hypovolaemia,
Hypokalaemia (Davidson)/hyperkalemia/ metabolic imbalance, Hypothermia/ hyperthermia
(Davidson) and (4T) ie. Thrombosis ( coronary or pulmonary), Tension pneumothorax, Tamponade (
cardiac), Toxins and drugs (ghai)

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a differential diagnosis of ST-segment elevation in ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Hypocalcemia Explanation: Clinical conditions - EKG findings ?
Hypothermia - Convex elevation of J point (Osborn wave) ? Hypocalcemia - Prolonged QT interval (ST
portion) ? Hypercalcemia - Shortens QT interval ? Hypokalemia - Prominent U waves. Prolongation of
the QT interval ? Hyperkalemia - Narrowing and tenting of T waves, demining P-wave amplitude, and
widening of QRS interval. Severe hyperkalemia causes cardiac arrest with a sine-wave" pattern
followed by asystole. ? Digitalis toxicity - Shortens QT interval, often with characteristic "scooping" of
ST-T wave complex (digitalis effect) ? Subarachnoid hemorrhage(CVA) - Marked QT prolongation,
sometimes with deep, wide T wave inversion (CVAT-wave pattern) Prolongation of the QT interval is
also seen with drugs: class IA antiarrhythmic s and related drugs (e.g. quinidine, disopyramide, procainamide,
tricyclic antidepressants, phenothiazines) and class III agents (e.g., amiodarone,
dofetilide, sotalol, ibutilide).

questions.text: According to the modified WHO classification of Heart Disease in Pregnancy, which cardiac lesion is a contraindication for pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Pulmonary arterial hypertension

Explanation: Modified WHO Classification of Heart Disease in Pregnancy WHO
• Uncomplicated, small or mild pulmonary stenosis, patent ductus arteriosus, mitral valve prolapse
• Successfully repaired simple lesions (atrial or ventricular septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, partially anomalous pulmonary venous drainage).
• Isolated atrial or ventricular ectopic beats WHO III
• Mechanical valve
• Systemic right ventricle
• Fontan circulation
• Cyanotic heart disease (unrepaired)
• Other complex congenital heart disease
• Aortic dilation 40-45 mm in Marfan syndrome
• Aortic dilation 45-50 mm in the bicuspid aortic valve WHO II (If otherwise well and uncomplicated)
• Unoperated atrial or ventricular septal defect
• Repaired tetralogy of Fallot
• Most arrhythmias

WHO II-III (Depending on the individual)
• Mild left ventricular impairment
• Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
• Native or tissue valvular heart disease is not considered WHO I or IV
• Marfan syndrome without aortic dissection
• Aorta < 45>
• Repaired coarctation

WHO IV (Pregnancy contraindicated)
• Pulmonary arterial hypertension
• Severe systemic ventricular dysfunction (LVEF <30> II)
• Previous peripartum cardiomyopathy with any residual impairment of left ventricular function
• Severe MS, severe symptomatic AS
• Marfan syndrome with aorta dilated >45 mm
• Aortic dilation >50 mm in the bicuspid aortic valve

• Native severe aortic coarctation

questions.text: A patient with atrial fibrillation on regular treatment presents with photosensitivity, skin discoloration, and peripheral neuropathy. Which drug may be implicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Amiodarone Explanation: Anti-arrhythmic drugs, class, their uses, and
side effects. Class I 1. Disopyramide Use - Prevention and treatment of atrial and ventricular
tachyarrhythmias Side effects - Myocardial depression, hypotension, dry mouth, urinary retention. 2.
Lidocaine Use- Treatment and short-term prevention of VT and VF Side effects - Myocardial
depression, delirium, convulsions 3. Mexiletine Use - Prevention and treatment of ventricular
tachyarrhythmias Side effects - Myocardial depression, gastrointestinal irritation, delirium, dizziness,
tremor, nystagmus, ataxia 4. Flecainide 5. Propafenone Use - Prevention and treatment of atrial and
ventricular tachyarrhythmias Side effects - Myocardial depression, dizziness Class II 1. Atenolol 2.
Bisoprolol 3. Metoprolol Use - T/t and prevention of SVT and AF, prevention of ventricular ectopics,
and exercise-induced VF Side effects - Myocardial depression, bradycardia, bronchospasm,
depression, nightmares, cold peripheries Class III 1. Amiodarone Use - Serious or resistant atrial and
ventricular tachyarrhythmias Side effects - Photosensitivity, skin discoloration, corneal deposits,
thyroid dysfunction, alveolitis, nausea and vomiting, hepatotoxicity, peripheral neuropathy, torsades
de pointes; potentiates digoxin and warfarin 2. Dronedarone Use - Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation Side
effects - Renal and hepatic dysfunction requiring regular blood monitoring 3. Sotalol Use - AF, rarely
ventricular tachyarrhythmias Side effects - Can cause torsades de pointes Class IV 1. Verapamil Use -
Verapamil Teatment of SVT, control of AF Side effects - Myocardial depression, hypotension,
bradycardia, constipation Other ? Atropine Use - T/t of bradycardia and/or hypotension due to vagal
overactivity Side effects - Dry mouth, thirst, blurred vision atrial and ventricular extrasystoles ?
Adenosine Use -T/t of SVT, aid in the diagnosis of unidentified tachycardia Side effects -Flushing,
dyspnoea, chest pain, Avoid in asthma ? Digoxin Use - T/t and prevention of SVT, rate control of AF
Side effects - Gastrointestinal disturbance, xanthopasia, arrhythmias

questions.text:
Risk factors for the development of COPD include which of the following? 
1. Tobacco smoking 
2. Recurrent infection 
3. Coal dust exposure 
4. High socio-economic status 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: Risk factors for the development of chronic
obstructive pulmonary disease Environmental factors: Tobacco smoke, indoor air pollution (cooking
with biomass fuels in confined areas in developing countries), occupational exposures, such as coal
dust, silica, and cadmium Low birth weight: may reduce optimal lung function in young adult life Lung

growth: childhood infections or maternal smoking may affect the growth of the lung during childhood,
resulting in a lower maximally attained lung function in adult life Infections: recurrent infection may
accelerate the decline in FEV1; persistence of adenovirus in lung tissue may alter the local
inflammatory response, predisposing to lung damage; HIV infection is associated with emphysema
Low socioeconomic status, cannabis smoking Host factors: Genetic factors: al-antitrypsin deficiency;
other COPD susceptibility genes are likely to be identified Airway hyper-reactivity

questions.text:
Which of the following are the non-metastatic extra-pulmonary manifestations of lung cancer? 
1. Carcinoid syndrome 
2. Nephrotic syndrome 
3. Horner's syndrome 
4. Lambert-Eaton syndrome 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 1, 2, and 4 Explanation: Non-metastatic extrapulmonary manifestations
of lung cancer are: ? Endocrine: Inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (ADH, vasopressin) secretion,
causing hyponatremia, ectopic adrenocorticotrophic hormone secretion(ACTH), hypercalcemia due to
secretion of parathyroid hormone-related peptides, carcinoid syndrome, gynecomastia. ?
Neurological: Polyneuropathy, myelopathy, cerebellar degeneration, myasthenia (Lambert—Eaton
syndrome) ? Other: Digital clubbing, hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy, nephrotic syndrome,
polymyositis, dermatomyositis, eosinophilia Regional spread of tumor in the thorax (by contiguous
growth or by metastasis to regional lymph nodes) may cause tracheal obstruction, esophageal
compression with dysphagia, recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness, phrenic nerve palsy with

elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea, and sympathetic nerve paralysis with Homer's
syndrome.

questions.text: A 60-year-old obese person (weighing 110 kg) has been complaining of excessive sleepiness in the daytime, morning headache, irritability, and mood disturbances. The patient also has a history of dry mouth, nocturnal heartburn, and diaphoresis of the chest and neck. Which one of the following will be the best investigation to diagnose the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Overnight Polysomnogram Explanation: This is a case of Obstructive
Sleep Apnea/Hypopnea Syndrome. Some important points regarding OSASH ? Clinical feature: -
Snoring (a most common complaint) gasping or snorting during sleep, dyspnea is unusual, and its
absence usually distinguishes OSAHS from paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, nocturnal asthma, and
acid reflux with laryngospasm. Frequent awakening or sleep disruption, which is more common
among women and older (M>F as in Davidson). The most common daytime symptom is excessive
sleepiness, difficulty maintaining alertness or involuntary periods of dozing, and fatigue. Other
symptoms are dry mouth, nocturnal heartburn, diaphoresis of the chest and neck, nocturia, morning
headaches, trouble concentrating, irritability, and mood disturbances. Difficulty falling asleep and
maintaining sleep are characteristics of insomnia disorders but may occur with OSAHS, especially in
women. Patients may exhibit hypertension and regional (central) obesity, as indicated by a large
waist and neck circumference. ? An overnight polysomnogram is the gold standard for diagnosis. A
negative in-laboratory polysomnogram usually rules out OSAHS. False-negative studies can result if
there was insufficient REM sleep or inadequate supine sleep during testing. Various imaging studies,
including cephalometric radiography, MRI, CT, and fiberoptic endoscopy, can be used to identify
anatomic risk factors for OSAHS. ? As appropriate, treatment should aim to reduce weight, optimize
sleep duration (7-9 h), regulate sleep schedules, avoid sleeping in the supine position, treat nasal
allergies, increase physical activity, and eliminate alcohol ingestion. ? The major risk factors are
obesity (40-60%) and male sex. Others include mandibular retrognathia and micrognathia, a positive
family history of OSAHS, genetic syndromes that reduce upper airway patency (e.g., Down syndrome,
Treacher-Collins syndrome), adenotonsillar hypertrophy (especially in children), menopause (in
women), and endocrine (e.g., acromegaly, hypothyroidism). ? High risks for OSAHS-related
morbidities are hypertension, DM, and cardiac and cerebrovascular diseases. ? CPAP is the standard
medical therapy with the highest level of evidence for efficacy. Side effects

questions.text:
Protein-losing enteropathy due to obstruction of intestinal lymphatic vessels is seen in which of the following conditions? 
1. Intestinal lymphangiectasia 
2. Constrictive pericarditis 
3. Eosinophilic gastroenteritis 
4. Whipple's disease 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 1, 2 and 4 1. Intestinal lymphangiectasia: This condition is characterized
by dilated and dysfunctional lymphatic vessels in the small intestine. This directly leads to the
leakage of lymph (which is rich in protein) into the intestinal lumen, causing protein-losing
enteropathy. This is a primary cause. 2. Constrictive pericarditis: This is a heart condition where the
pericardium (the sac around the heart) becomes thick and stiff, impairing the heart's ability to fill
with blood. This can lead to increased systemic venous pressure, which in turn can increase
lymphatic pressure in the abdomen and cause secondary intestinal lymphangiectasia and thus
protein-losing enteropathy. 3. Eosinophilic gastroenteritis: This is an inflammatory condition
characterized by eosinophil infiltration of parts of the gastrointestinal tract. While it can cause
malabsorption and other GI symptoms, its primary mechanism for protein loss is typically not
obstruction of intestinal lymphatic vessels, but rather inflammation and mucosal damage. 4.
Whipple's disease: This is a rare systemic infectious disease caused by the bacterium Tropheryma
whipplei. It primarily affects the small intestine, leading to malabsorption. A key feature of Whipple's
disease is the infiltration of the lamina propria with foamy macrophages, which can obstruct
lymphatic flow in the intestine. This lymphatic obstruction is a known cause of protein-losing
enteropathy in Whipple's disease. Based on this analysis, the conditions that cause protein-losing
enteropathy due to obstruction of intestinal lymphatic vessels are: 1. Intestinal lymphangiectasia
(primary lymphatic obstruction) 2. Constrictive pericarditis (leading to secondary lymphatic
obstruction/lymphangiectasia due to increased venous pressure) 4. Whipple's disease (due to
macrophage infiltration causing lymphatic obstruction)

questions.text:
Consider the following statements with regard to "Anorexia of Aging" : 
1. Declining chemosensory function (smell and taste) 
2. Reduced efficiency of chewing 
3. Slowed gastric emptying
 4. Alterations in the neuro-endocrine axis 
Which of the above statements are associated with early satiety and weight loss in the elderly?
questions.solution:
\Correct Answer (C) 1, 2, 3 and 4 Explanation: Several important age-associated physiologic
changes also predispose elderly persons to weight loss, such as declining chemosensory function
(smell and taste), reduced efficiency of chewing, slowed gastric emptying, and alterations in the
neuroendocrine axis, including changes in levels of leptin, cholecystokinin, neuropeptide Y, and other
hormones and peptides. These changes are associated with early satiety and a decline in both
appetite and the hedonistic appreciation of food. Collectively it contributes to the "anorexia of aging'
It may be accompanied by social isolation and/or poverty, further contributing to undernutrition

questions.text: The quadruple therapy regime (or OBMT regime) for Helicobacter Pylori eradication comprises which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Omeprazole, Bismuth subcitrate, Metronidazole Tetracycline
Explanation: Antibiotic regimen for H. pylori eradication Regimen 1: OCM{Should be used only for
populations in which the prevalence of clarithromycin-resistant strains is known to} Omeprazole (20
mg bid) or other PPI, Clarithromycin (500 mg bid) Metronidazole (500 mg bid) Line of treatment - 2nd
Duration - 14 days Efficacy - 85-90% Regimen 2: OCA{Should be used only for populations in which
the prevalence of clarithromycin-resistant strains is known to} Omeprazole (20 mg bid) or other PPI,
Clarithromycin (500 mg bid), Amoxicillin (1 g bid) Line of treatment - 2nd Duration - 14 days Efficacy -
90% Regimen 3: OBTM Omeprazole (20 mg bid) or other PPI, Bismuth subsalicylate (2 tabs qid),
Tetracycline HC1 (500 mg qid), Metronidazole (500 mg tid) Line of treatment - 1st Duration - 14 days
Regimen 4: concomitant Omeprazole (20 mg bid)or other PPI, Amoxicillin (1 g bid), Clarithromycin
13
(500 mg bid), Tinidazole (500 mg bid) Line of treatment - 1st Duration - 14 days Efficacy - 85%
Regimen 5: OAL Omeprazole or other PPI, (20 mg bid), Amoxicillin(1 g bid) Levofloxacin (500 mg bid)
Line of treatment - 2nd or 3rd Duration - 10 days Efficacy - 80%

questions.text: A renal transplant offers the best chance of long-term survival in ESRD and is cost-effective. Which one of the following is not a contraindication to renal transplantation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Children less than one year Explanation: Although among all options
given above active malignancy is the only absolute contraindication if I have to choose one correct
answer I will like to go with option "V. In the UPSC answer key, this question is deleted. i.e. the
answer is "X" Contraindication of renal transplantation:- Absolute ? Active malignant disease ? Active
infection ? Unreconstructable peripheral vascular disease, vasculitis ? Severe cardiac or pulmonary
disease ? Active IV drug abuse ? Significant psychosocial barriers that interfere with the patient's
ability to comply with a complex medical regimen Relative ? Limited life expectancy ? History of
nonadherence to medication regimen ? History of noncompliance with dialysis ? Financial barriers ?
Psychiatric issues ? Renal disease with a high recurrence rate (active lupus, autoimmune disease) ?
Morbid obesity (BMI is center dependent) ? Frailty All patients with ESRD should be considered for
transplantation but many are not suitable due to a combination of comorbidity and advanced age
although many institutions do transplants for patient of advanced age and diabetes. For a young
infant, a recipient may need to weigh 810 kg to minimize the risk of thrombosis and to accommodate
adult-size kidneys. Transplantation of adult-size kidneys has been successful in children who weigh
<10>6 months) - Aspergillus, Nocardia, BK virus (polyoma), Herpes zoster, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis
C

questions.text: The presence of Beevor's sign on neurological examination is characteristic of a spinal cord lesion at which one of the following levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) T9-T10 Explanation; Beevor's sign: Lesions at T9-T10 paralyze the lower
but not the upper abdominal muscles, resulting in upward movement of the umbilicus when the
abdominal wall contracts. Useful markers of the sensory level on the trunk are the nipples (T4) and
umbilicus (T10). Leg weakness and disturbances of bladder and bowel function accompany the
paralysis.

questions.text: Visual hallucination is characteristic of which type of dementia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Diffuse Lewy body dementia Explanation Type – Characteristic Feature

1. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. – Quickly progressive (over months) and is associated with myoclonus 

2. Fronto-temporal dementia. – Typically presents with signs of temporal or frontal lobe dysfunction like Personality change, disinhibition, weight gain or compulsive eating, prominent apathy, compulsivity, loss of empathy for others, or progressive loss of speech fluency or single-word comprehension and by a relative sparing of memory and visuospatial abilities. Patients often develop axial rigidity, supranuclear gaze palsy, or a motor neuron disease reminiscent of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis 

3. Lewy body dementia. – Often start with early visual hallucinations, parkinsonism; proneness to delirium or sensitivity to psychoactive medications; rapid eye movement (REM) behavior disorder (RBD; the loss of skeletal muscle paralysis during dreaming); or Capgras syndrome (the delusion that a familiar person has been replaced by an impostor). 

4. Alzheimer's disease. – Gradual worsening, slowly progressive over several years, beginning with memory symptoms, but other early symptoms include difficulty with managing money, driving, shopping, following instructions, finding words, or navigating. 5. Vascular dementia. – H/o stroke or irregular stepwise deterioration, also commonly seen in the setting of hypertension, atrial fibrillation, peripheral vascular disease, and diabetes

questions.text:
Consider the following statements regarding Intracerebral Hemorrhage (ICH): 
1. It accounts for 35% of all strokes. 
2. Most common site of hypertensive ICH is the cerebral cortex. 
3. Use of cocaine and methamphetamine is a frequent cause of stroke at a young age. 
4. Hypertensive ICH usually results from the spontaneous rupture of a small penetrating artery deep in the brain. 
Which of the above statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 3 and 4 Explanation: ICH accounts for around 10% of all strokes, and
about 35-45% of patients die within the first month. Hypertension, coagulopathy, sympathomimetic
drugs (cocaine, methamphetamine), and cerebral amyloid angiopathy are the most common causes.
Advanced age and heavy alcohol consumption increase the risk while cocaine and methamphetamine
are one of the most important causes in the young. Hypertensive ICH- usually results from
spontaneous rupture of a small penetrating artery deep in the brain. The most common sites are the
basal ganglia [especially the putamen (MC site)), thalamus, cerebellum, and pans. Most hypertensive
ICHs initially develop over 30-90 min, whereas those associated with anticoagulant therapy may
evolve for as long as 24-48 h. Lobar Hemorrhage: The major neurologic deficit with an occipital
hemorrhage is hemianopsia; with a left temporal hemorrhage, aphasia, and delirium; with a parietal
hemorrhage, hemisensory loss; and with frontal hemorrhage, arm weakness.

questions.text: A 21-year-old young lady presents with unilateral facial weakness. She is unable to close her eye on the affected side and there are vesicles in her ear. She is suffering from
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 7th Cranial Nerve Palsy Explanation: Bell's palsy - Most common causes
of facial weakness, ipsilateral lower motor neuron lesion of the 74 nerve (no sparing of forehead
muscle), affecting all ages and both sexes; more common following upper respiratory tract infections,
in pregnancy, diabetes, immunosuppression and hypertension. Onset is rarely abrupt; with maximal
weakness being attained by 48hr. Pain behind the ear may precede the paralysis for one or two days.
Loss of unilateral taste sensation and hyperacusis may be present. The corner of the mouth droops,
the creases and skinfolds are effaced, the forehead is unfurrowed, and the eyelids will not close.
Upon attempted closure of the lids, the eye on the paralyzed side rolls upward (Bell's phenomenon).
Mild CSF lymphocytosis. The presence of incomplete paralysis in the first week is the most favorable
prognostic sign. Herpes simplex virus type 1 DNA was frequently detected in endoneurial fluid and
posterior auricular muscle, suggesting that a reactivation of this virus in the geniculate ganglion.
Reactivation of varicella-zoster virus is associated with Bell's palsy second most frequent cause. T/t-
Glucocorticoid improves recovery if given within 72hours. Spontaneous recovery within 12 weeks The
Ramsay Hunt syndrome, caused by reactivation of herpes zoster in the geniculate ganglion, consists
of a severe facial palsy associated with a vesicular eruption in the external auditory canal and
sometimes in the pharynx and other parts of the cranial integument; often the eighth cranial nerve is
affected as well.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding G6PD enzyme deficiency are correct? 
1. It is an Xlinked deficiency. 
2. Geographical distribution parallels the malaria belt. 
3. Consumption of fava beans is protective. 
4. Transfusion support may be life saving. 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 1, 2 and 4 Explanation: Some important point regarding glucose-6-
phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency ? The enzyme (G6PD) have a role in the hexose
monophosphate shunt pathway. It is the most common human enzymopathy, affecting 10% of the
population, with a geographical distribution that parallels the malaria belt because heterozygotes are
protected from malarial parasitization. The enzyme is encoded by a gene on the X chromosome. The
deficiency affects males and rare homozygous females but females are carriers. The most common
types associated with normal activity are the B+ enzyme present in most Caucasians and 70% of
Afro-Caribbeans; deficiency in Caucasian and East Asian populations is more severe, with enzyme
levels as low as 1%. ? Clinical features: Acute drug-induced hemolysis due to analgesics( aspirin,
phenacetin, etc), antimalarials (primaquine, quinine, chloroquine, pyrimethamine), antibiotics (
sulphonamides, nitrofurantoin, ciprofloxacin), miscellaneous (quinidine, probenecid, vitamin K,
dapsone), chronic compensated hemolysis, infection or acute illness, neonatal jaundice (may be a
feature of the B- enzyme), favism (acute hemolysis after ingestion of broad beans) ? Lab diagnosis:-
The blood film will show: bite cells (red cells with a 'bite' of membrane missing), blister cells (red cells
with surface blistering of the membrane), irregularly shaped small cells, polychromasia reflecting the
reticulocytosis, Heinz bodies within the red cell, cytoplasm with a supravital stain such as methyl
violet. Indirect or direct assessment of G6DP level, increase reticulocyte level. ? Treatment is blood
transfusion, withdrawal of cause.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common dermatologic manifestation of Diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Xerosis Explanation: Most common skin manifestations of DM are xerosis and pruritus and are usually relieved by skin moisturizers. Necrobiosis lipoidica is an uncommon disorder that has some histological features in common with granuloma annulare. The
lesion has a characteristic yellow, waxy, atrophic appearance, often with a violaceous edge: typically appears on the shins and is prone to ulceration after trauma. There is a strong association with diabetes: most patients with necrobiosis lipoidica have or develop diabetes, although less than 19% of diabetic patients develop necrobiosis lipoidica. Treatment is difficult and includes very potent topical or intralesional glucocorticoids, topical calcineurin inhibitors, PUVA or UVAl phototherapy, and systemic immunosuppression. Acanthosis nigricans (hyperpigmented velvety plaques seen on the neck, axilla, or extensor surfaces) is sometimes a feature of severe insulin resistance and
accompanying diabetes.

questions.text: Which one of the following conditions may result in hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Critical illness Explanation: some important points regarding hypoglycemia: ? Hypoglycemia may be documented by Whipple's triad: 
(a) symptoms consistent with hypoglycemia, 
(b) a low plasma glucose concentration measured with a precise method, and 
(c) relief of symptoms after the plasma glucose level is raised. The lower limit of the fasting plasma glucose
concentration is normally around 70 mg/dL (3.9 mol/L) [Davidson 54 mg/dL. (3.9 mmol/L)] ? Causes
are: ?Insulin, ?C-peptide- alcohol, drugs, critical illnesses (hepatic, renal or cardiac failure, sepsis)
hypopituitarism (rare), primary adrenocortical failure (rare in adults), non-islet cell tumor (eg.
sarcoma), inborn errors of metabolism, ?insulin, ?C-peptide-exogenous insulin, ?Insulin, ?C-peptideinsulinoma,
sulphonylureas, other drugs, hyperinsulinism of infancy ? Symptoms are:- Autonomic
(sweating, trembling pounding heart. hunger, anxiety) neuroglycopenic (delirium, drowsiness, speech
difficulty inability to concentrate, incoordination, Irritability, anger), others (nausea tiredness,
headache). In children, behavioral changes like naughtiness or irritability are more prominent, while
in older people visual disturbance and ataxia are more prominent

questions.text: Which one of the following oral anti-diabetic drugs acts on renal proximal tubules?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) sGLT-2 inhibitors Explanation: Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter 2
(SGLT2) Inhibitors (Empagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and canagliflozin) These agents lower the blood
glucose by selectively inhibiting this co-transporter, which is expressed almost exclusively in the
proximal, convoluted tubule of the kidney. It inhibits glucose reabsorption, leading to increase
glycosuria. Inhibition of SGLT2 on the alpha cell may lead to increased glucagon and consequently
liver production of glucose and ketones. SGLT2 act on distal tubules Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors
(Acarbose and miglitol) delay carbohydrate absorption in the gut by inhibiting disaccharidases. The
incretin effect is the augmentation of insulin secretion when a glucose stimulus is given orally rather
than IV, which reflects the release of incretin peptides from the gut.The incretin hormones are
primarily glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) and gastric inhibitory polypeptide (GIP), which potentiate
insulin secretion. These are rapidly broken down by dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP-4). The incretin effect
is diminished in type 2 diabetes. DPP-4 inhibitors (sitagliptin, vildagliptin, saxagliptin, linagliptin, and
alogliptin), prevent breakdown and therefore enhance concentrations of endogenous GLP-1 and GIP
GLP-1 receptor agonists (? Insulin, ? glucagon, slow gastric emptying, satiety) have a similar structure
to GLP-1. Given subcutaneously. It delays gastric emptying and, at the level of the hypothalamus,
decreases appetite. GLP-1 receptor agonists include exenatide (twice daily), exenatide modifiedrelease
(once weekly), liraglutide (once daily), lixisenatide (once daily), and albiglutide (once weekly).
Thiazolidinediones (rosiglitazone) reduce insulin resistance by binding to the peroxisome proliferatoractivated
receptor Y (PPAR-Y) nuclear receptor.

questions.text:
Hirsutism is seen in which of the following ? 
1. Polycystic ovarian syndrome 
2. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia 
3. Hypothyroidism 
4. Ovarian tumor 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 1, 2 and 4 Explanation: Hirsutism: - Excessive growth of terminal hair
(the thick, pigmented hair usually associated with the adult male chest) in an androgen-dependent
distribution in women (upper lip, chin, chest, back, lower abdomen, thigh, forearm); Most often
idiopathic or the consequence of androgen excess associated with PCOS. Can be distinguished from
hypertrichosis, in which there is generalized excessive growth of villus hair (the thin, non-pigmented
hair that is typically found all over the body). Testosterone is the most important circulating
androgen, but it is a precursor hormone in mediating hirsutism. ? Causes ofHirsutism:-Gonadal
hyperandrogenism (Ovarian hyperandrogenism, polycystic ovary syndrome/functional ovarian
hyperandrogenism, ovarian steroidogenic blocks, syndromes of extreme insulin resistance, ovarian
neoplasms, hyperthecosis), Adrenal hyperandrogenism (premature adrenarche, functional adrenal
hyperandrogenism, congenital adrenal hyperplasia, abnormal cortisol action/metabolism, adrenal
neoplasms), Cushing's syndrome, hyperprolactinemia, acromegaly, peripheral androgen
overproduction (obesity, idiopathic), Pregnancy-related hyperandrogenism (hyperreactive luteinalis,
thecoma of pregnancy), Drugs (androgens, oral contraceptives containing androgenic progestins,
minoxidil, phenytoin, diazoxide, cyclosporine, valproic acid) ? Treatment: 0CP is the first-line
endocrine treatment for hirsutism and acne. Estrogenic component (ethinyl estradiol or mestranol)
and progesterone (norgestimate (nonandrogenic), drospirenone, an analogue of spironolactone that
has both anti mineralocorticoid and antiandrogenic activities, is used. Glucocorticoids may be used
for CAH. Cyproterone acetate is an antiandrogen, and spironolactone, a mineralocorticoid antagonist,
is also a weak antiandrogen may be used. Flutamide is a potent nonsteroidal antiandrogen,
Finasteride/ dutasteride has beneficial effects on hirsutism have been reported.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct regarding hypothyroidism ? 
1. It is more common in females. 
2. Autoimmunity is a rare aetiopathogenesis. 
3. In pregnancy, an increased dose of levothyroxine is required. 
4. Suppressed TSH is a risk factor for osteoporosis. 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 1, 3 and 4 Explanation: Some important point regarding Hypothyroidism:-. 
Features: F: M = 6:1. Autoimmune disease (Hashimoto's thyroiditis) and iatrogenic thyroid failure following "I or surgical treatment of thyrotoxicosis account for over 90% of cases,
except in areas where iodine deficiency is endemic. Some patients remain symptomatic despite normalization of TSH after taking levothyroxine and may wish to take extra levothyroxine, which suppresses TSH. However, suppressed TSH is a risk factor for osteoporosis and atrial fibrillation. Thyroid hormone requirements are increased by up to 45% during pregnancy in levothyroxinetreated hypothyroid women. Investigation: In primary hypothyroidism due to intrinsic cause Measurements of serum T3 are unhelpful because they do not differentiate between euthyroidism and hypothyroidism. If the TSH is elevated, serum T4 is low and TSH is elevated, usually in excess of 20 mIU/L. an unbound T4 level is needed to confirm the presence of clinical hypothyroidism, but T4 is 25 inferior to TSH as a screening test because it does not detect subclinical hypothyroidism. Etiology may be identified by the presence of TPO and Tg antibodies, which are present in >95% of patients with autoimmune hypothyroidism. Other laboratory findings in hypothyroidism may include increased creatine phosphokinase, elevated cholesterol and triglycerides, and anemia (usually normocytic or macrocytic) Treatment - Levothyroxine replacement. Start with a low dose of 50 ug per day for 3 weeks, then 100 μg per day for 3 weeks, and finally to a maintenance dose of 100-150 μg per day. Levothyroxine has a half-life of 7 days so always be taken as a single daily dose and TSH repeat after 6 weeks to adjust the dose. Reduction in weight and periorbital puffiness occurs quickly but the restoration of skin and hair texture and resolution of any effusions may take 3-6 months. Autoimmune polyendocrine syndromes (APS) ? Type 1 (APECED= autoimmune poly-endocrinopathy - candidiasis - ectodermal dystrophy) consists of Addison's disease, Hypoparathyroidism, type 1 diabetes, primary hypothyroidism, chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis, nail dystrophy, dental enamel hypoplasia ? Type 2 (Schmidt's syndrome) consists Addison's disease, primary hypothyroidism, Graves' disease, pernicious anemia, primary Hypogonadism, type 1 diabetes, vitiligo, coeliac disease, myasthenia gravis

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1, 2 and 3. Explanation: Adrenal insufficiency: The most common is ACTH deficiency (secondary adrenocortical failure), usually because of inappropriate withdrawal of chronic glucocorticoid therapy or a pituitary tumor. Features of an acute adrenal crisis include circulatory shock with severe hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and, in some instances, hypoglycemia and hypercalcemia.

questions.text: The most common acid-base disturbance in critically ill patients is :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Chronic respiratory alkalosis Explanation: Chronic respiratory alkalosis is the most common acid-base disturbance in critically ill patients. Delirium is extremely common in critically ill patients. In the ICU, illnesses are frequently categorized by degree of severity. Many
severity-of-illness (SOI) scoring systems have been developed and validated over the past. The most commonly utilized scoring systems are the SOFA (Sequential Organ Failure Assessment), the APACHE (Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation), and the SAPS (Simplified Acute Physiology Score)
systems.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old traveler from the United Kingdom desires anti-malaria prophylaxis before traveling to India. He has a history of seizures and depression. Which of the following drugs can be used? 
1. Doxycycline 
2. Atovaquone + Proguanil 
3. Chloroquine + Proguanil 
4. Mefloquine 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: Some important point regarding antimalarial
prophylaxis: Malaria prophylaxis recommended according to the knowledge of local patterns of drug
sensitivity in Plasmodium species and the likelihood of acquiring malarial infection. When there is
uncertainty, drugs effective against resistant P. falciparum should be used which are atovaquone+
proguanil (Malarone), doxycycline, or mefloquine. Pregnant women planning to visit malarious areas
should be warned about the potential risks and advised to avoid all nonessential travel. Mefloquine is
the only drug used in the second and third trimesters for pregnant women traveling to areas with
drug-resistant malaria. Chloroquine and proguanil are regarded as safe, but there are now very few
regions where these drugs can be recommended for protection. Travelers should start taking
antimalarial drugs 2 days to 2 weeks before departure and continue for 4 weeks after the traveler has
left the endemic area, except if atovaquone+ proguanil or primaquine has been taken; these drugs
have significant activities against the liver stage of the infection and can be discontinued 1 week
after departure from the endemic area. Mefloquine is contraindicated in persons allergic to this drug
or related compounds (eg, quinine and quinidine) and persons with active or recent depression,
generalized anxiety disorder, psychosis, schizophrenia, other major psychiatric disorders, or seizures.
Doxycycline is contraindicated in children c8 years and in pregnant women > 15 weeks of gestation.
Atovaquone-proguanil is contraindicated in persons with severe renal impairment (creatinine
clearance rate, 30 mL/min). It is not recommended for children weighing 5 kg, pregnant women, or
women breastfeeding infants weighing <5 kg.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements with regard to Amphotericin B: 
1. It is a narrow-spectrum antifungal agent. 
2. It can cause nephrotoxicity. 
3. It lacks oral preparation. 
4. Its lipid formulations are less toxic, 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 2, 3 and 4 Explanation: Amphotericin B deoxycholate is broadestspectrum
antifungal agent and causes cell death by binding to ergosterol and damaging the fungal
cytoplasmic membrane. It lacks oral I preparation. Its long half-life enables once-daily administration.
CSF penetration is poor. Adverse effects include immediate anaphylaxis, other infusion-related
reactions (fever, chills, and nausea), and nephrotoxicity. It may be ameliorated by concomitant
infusion of normal saline. Irreversible nephrotoxicity with large dose; Lipid formulations of
Amphotericin B have been developed to reduce its toxicity and have replaced AmB deoxycholate.
Lipid formulations are used in invasive fungal disease, as empirical therapy in patients withm
neutropenic fever, and also in visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: Which one of the following molds causes mucormycosis, commonly known as 'black fungus'?

Lichtheimia (formerly Absidia) spp., Rhizomucor spp, Mucor spp. and Rhizopus spp. Among the
Mucorales, Rhizopus oryzae and R. Delmar are the most common causes of mucormycosis in the
Western Hemisphere. Mucormycosis is a black fungus, Candida is a white fungus.

questions.text:
Which of the following are tricyclic antidepressants ? 
1. Amitriptyline 
2. Dosulepin 
3. Paroxetine 
4. Imipramine 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 1, 2 and 4 Explanation: Antidepressant drug -Tricyclic antidepressants
(Amitriptyline, Imipramine, Dosulepin or Dothiepin, Doxepin, Trimipramine, Clomipramine,
Nortriptyline). Selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors (SSRIs)-(Citalopram, Escitalopram, Fluoxetine,
Fluvoxamine, Sertraline, Paroxetine), Monoamine oxidase Inhibitors (Phenelzine, Tranylcypromine,
Moclobemide), Noradrenaline (norepinephrine) re-uptake inhibitors and SSRIs (Venlafaxine.
Duloxetine). Noradrenaline and specific serotonergic inhibitor (Mirtazapine). Atypical antidepressant
(Trazodone, Mianserin, Bupropion, Amoxapine, Mirtazapine) Painful Conditions That Respond to
Tricyclic Antidepressants- Postherpetic neuralgia, diabetic neuropathy fibromyalgia, tension
headache, migraine, rheumatoid arthritis, chronic low back pain, cancer, central post-stroke pain.

questions.text: Cardiac outflow tract defect, thymic hypoplasia, cleft palate, and hypocalcemia are clinical features of which gene disorder?
questions.solution:
\Correct Answer (D) DiGeorge syndrome Explanation: Recurrent deletions, microdeletions,
and contiguous gene defects 1. Di Georgel ? Locus - 22q11.2 ? Clinical features - Cardiac outflow tract
defects, distinctive facial appearance, thymic hypoplasia, cleft palate, and velocardiofacial syndrome
hypocalcemia. The major gene seems to be TBXI (cardiac defects and cleft palate) 2. Angelman's
syndrome ? Locus - 15q11-q13 ? Clinical features - Distinctive facial appearance, absent speech,
electroencephalogram (EEG) abnormality, characteristic gait. Severe mental retardation, hypotonia,
epilepsy, and inappropriate laughing bouts. Having deletions involving the maternal copy of this
region on chromosome 15. 3. Williams' syndrome (idiopathic infantile hypercalcemia) ? Locus -
7q11.23 ? Clinical features - Multiple congenital development defects including supravalvular aortic
stenosis, mental retardation, and a distinctive facial appearance (elfin facies), in association with
hypercalcemia and diffuse arteriopathy, with a "cocktail-like" personality (in adult) due to abnormal
sensitivity to vitamin D. Major gene for supravalvular aortic stenosis is elastin 4. Smith-Magenis
syndrome ? Locus - 17p11.2 ? Clinical features - Distinctive facial appearance and behavioral
phenotype,self-injury, and rapid eye movement (REM) Sleep abnormalities. The major gene seems to
be RAIl

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is diagnosed with dengue fever. She has abdominal pain and persistent vomiting. Examination reveals normal blood pressure but the hematocrit is found to be increased. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial fluid management ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Ringer lactate @7 mL/kg/hour Explanation: Management of Dengue ?
Undifferentiated fever: Patients have non-specific symptoms. t/t is paracetamol and monitoring ?
Dengue infection without warning signs: fever, bodyache, rashes or minor bleeding may be treated
symptomatically. Salicylates and other NSAID should avoid; taken plenty of fluid to be taken ?
Dengue with warning signs: dengue infection with following sign need hospitalization: (i) abdominal
pain or tenderness, (ii) persistent vomiting, (iii) clinical fluid accumulation, (iv) mucosal bleeding, (v)
lethargy, restlessness, (vi) liver enlarged >2 cm, (vii) increase in PCV with concurrent or rapid
decrease in platelet count. T/t- RL or NS at a rate of 7 mL/kg/hour. After one hour, if PCV decreased
and vitals are improving; fluid infusion decreased to 5 mL/kg over next hour and than 3 mL/kg/ hour
for 24-48 hours with frequent monitoring of PCV and vital parameters. If at 1 hour, the PCV is rises
and vital parameters not improved the infusion rate should be 10 mL/kg /for one hour ? no
improvement ?infusion should 15 mL/kg in the 3rd hour no improvement ? colloids are given at 10
mL/kg. If parameter stable infusion reduce over 24-48 hours. ? Severe dengue: (i) Severe plasma
leakage leading to shock or fluid accumulation with respiratory distress; (ii) Severe bleeding; (iii)
Severe organ involvement: high AST, ALT> 1000 U/L, impaired consciousness or involvement of heart
and other organs. T/T- Hospitalise and infuse NS or RL at 10-20 ml/kg over 1 hour if blood pressure is
unrecordable (earlier known as dengue shock syndrome, DSS IV). In critically sick children, two IV line
(one for NS and other for 5

questions.text: A child presents with headache and vomiting in the emergency room following a fall from the bed. Which one of the following treatment modalities is not recommended in the emergency room ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Therapeutic lumbar puncture Explanation: Treatment options for
severely raised ICP ? Remove intracranial mass ? Ventilate to reduce pCO, (4-4.5 kPa) ? Drain CSF by
ventriculostomy ? Steroids, mannitol, barbiturates, frusemide ? Hypothermia ± Management of head
injury: Once any intracranial hematoma has been evacuated: ? Patient should then be admitted to an
intensive care unit and ventilated to pCO, of 4-4.5 kPa. . The head of the bed should be positioned
40° up (ghai 30° up). ? Patient should be given analgesia (fentanyl), sedated using propofol or
midazolam, and paralyzed (atracurium). ? Diuretics such as mannitol 20% (0.5 to 1 g/kg as IV bolus;
repeat 8 hourly for 48 hours) or hypertonic saline. Administer hypertonic (3%) saline at 0.1-1 mUkg/hr
to maintain serum sodium at 145-155 mEq/L and frusemide to lower ICP. Dexamethasone has no
benefit Consider corticosteroids (oral or IV) for vasogenic edema (Ghai). ? Hyperventilation to a PaCO,
of 20-25 mmHg lies mainly on induction of cerebral vasoconstriction by this method and so reducing
38
ICP. ? Barbiturates reduce ICP by reducing cerebral blood flow and by protecting the brain from
damage by reducing its metabolic requirements.

questions.text: What will a baby with mild hypothermia feel like, when touched by the back of the hand of an examiner ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) The abdomen will be warm, but the hands and feet will be cold.
Explanation: Based on axillary temperature, hypothermia Normal body temperature is 36.5°C to
37.5°C, Hypothermia < 36> 37.5°C. Cold stress (or mild hypothermia)- 36.0
to 36.4°C, Moderate hypothermia- 32 to 35.9°C, Severe hypothermia- < 32°C. A low-reading
thermometer (up to 30°C) can be used for temperature measurement in neonates to correctly
identify severity of hypothermia. Baby's hands and feet and abdomen to be touched by back of
examiner's hand. ? If everything appears warm, baby has normal temperature. ? Warm abdomen but
cold feet and hands indicate mild to moderate hypothermia. Cold feet and hands as well as the
abdomen would indicate that the baby has severe hypothermia.

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations is/are seen in hypocalcemia ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Dilated cardiomyopathy Explanation: Some important point regarding
hypocalcemia ? Hypocalcemia (total calcium <8 mg/dL.) ionised calcium hypocalcemia (<1.1 mmol/L)
is important to define ? C/F- In the neonatal period, lethargy, jitteriness and poor feeding is
characteristic of hypocalcemia. It is commonest biochemical abnormality associated with neonatal
seizures. In the post-neonatal period, the commonest presentation is tetany. This is most commonly
observed in hands (adduction of thumbs along with extension of the proximal interphalangeal joints
and flexion of distal interphalangeal joints) and feet (flexion and internal rotation of lower limbs)
resulting in carpopedal spasm. ? Tapping the facial nerve at the angle of jaw results in contraction of
facial muscles (Chvostek sign). Inflating blood pressure cuff above the chillie blood pressure for more
than 5 minutes triggers spasm of the hand muscles (Trousseau sign). Hypocalcemia should be
considered in children with seizures, dilated cardiomyopathy and unexplained stridor. ? The diagnosis
is confirmed by the demonstration of prolonged QT.

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Which of the following could be a likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Congenital hypothyroidism Explanation: In galactosemia initially there is
unconjugated bilirubin due to hemolysis which may appear in 2-3 days. But later on their conjugated
bilirubin predominates. In hypothyroidism there is prolongation of physiological jaundice beyond 3
weeks. The condition in which jaundice appear after 72 hours are sepsis, neonatal hepatitis,
extrahepatic biliary atresia, breast milk jaundice, metabolic disorders. In Dubin Johnson syndrome
and Rotor syndrome there is conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Increased indirect bilirubin: Positive
Coombs test Iscimmunisation Rh, ABO, Other blood group Negative Coombs test?? ? High hemoglobin
(polycythemia) ? twin transfusion, maternal fetal transfusion, delayed cord clamping, small for
gestational age infant ? Normal or low hemoglobin (increase reticulocyte count)+characteristic red
cell morphology ? Spherocytosis, elliptocytosis, stomatocytosis, pyknocytosis, fragmented cells ?
Normal or low hemoglobin (increase reticulocyte count) ? non specific red cell morphology ? G6PD
deficiency, PK deficiency, other enzyme deficiency, DIC ? Normal or low hemoglobin (increase
reticulocyte count) normal red cell morphology ? Enclosed haemorrhage, increased enterohepatic
circulation, delayed or infrequent stooling, bowel obstruction, inadequate caloric intake, neonatal
asphyxia ? Normal or low hemoglobin (increase reticulocyte count) ? normal red cell morphology with
prolonged hyperbilirubinemia ? Gilbert syndrome, Down Syndrome, hypothyroidism, breast feeding,
Crigler-Najjar syndrome Increase direct bilirubin: Sepsis, intrauterine infection (toxoplasmosis,
cytomegalovirus, rubella, herpes, syphilis) paucity of bile ducts, disorder of bile acid metabolism,
severe hemolytic disease, biliary atresia, giant cell hepatitis, choledochal cyst, cystic fibrosis,
galactosemia, alpha -1 antitrypsin deficiency, tyrosinemia, hyperalimentation cholestasis.

A 3-year-old boy presents with parental concerns regarding delayed development, especially
speech. On observation, the clinician notes decreased eye contact, inattentiveness, unresponsive to
being called and toe walking. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Autism Spectrum Disorder

questions.text: Atomoxetine is prescribed to children with Autism Spectrum Disorder to control symptoms of :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Hyperactivity Explanation: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is
characterized by the triad of qualitative impairment of social behaviour, communication (verbal and
non-verbal) skills (delay in or lack of spoken language if speech is present, lack of ability to initiate or
sustain conversation) and associated stereotypic and restrictive behavioural patterns, with onset
before 3 years of age; prevalence is 1 to 2%. Genetic causes such as fragile X syndrome, tuberous
sclerosis, Angelman syndrome and metabolic diseases like phenylketonuria and hypothyroidism
account for 10% of cases. Treatment: Antipsychotics (risperidone, olanzapine) for anxiety and
aggression and repetitive behaviour; Methylphenidate for inattention, hyperactivity and impulsivity;
Alpha-2 agonists for (clonidine, atomoxetine) hyperactivity; Melatonin for sleep-related problems; Iron
supplements If deficiency is documented.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with difficulty in word recognition, word decoding abilities difficulty in spelling with normal listening comprehension. The most likely diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Dyslexia Explanation: Developmental dyslexia describes delayed,
disorganized reading and writing ability in children, usually with normal intelligence. poems may
include omissions, distortions, or substitutions of words, long hesitations, reversal of words, or simply
slow reading Difficulty ie writing is dysgraphia, impaired arithmetic skills is dyscalculia, and inability
to recognize familiar objects in agnosia.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the correct, schedule for home visits by an Accredited Social Health Activist for facility-born newborn babies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) On 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42 days of life Explanation: Home visits by
Accredited Social Health Activist (six for facility born babies, on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42; an extra
visit on day 1 for home births) Home based newborn care ? Interventions for Infants - Examination;
counsel for warmth; breastfeeding; hygiene; extra care of LBW babies; detection of sickness, referral
? Interventions for mother - Postpartum care and counseling for family planning ? Program driver -
ASHA paid Incentive for home care, birth weight record, birth registration, and immunization (BCG
first dose, OPV and pentavalent) Facility based newborn care ? Special Newborn Care Units (SNCUs) -
At district hospitals with specialized equipment including radiant warmers. These units have 12-16
beds with a staff of 3 physicians, 10 nurses, and 4 support staff to provide round-the-clock services
for newborns requiring special care, such as those with very low birth weight, neonatal
sepsis/pneumonia & common complications. ? Newborn Stabilization Units (NBSUs). - This unit
provides facilities for neonates from the periphery where babies can be stabilized through effective
care. These are set up in CHCs and provide services, Including resuscitation, provision of warmth,
initiation of breastfeeding, prevention of infection and cord care, and supportive care: oxygen. IV
fluids, provision for monitoring of vital signs, and referral. ? Newborn Care Corners (NBCCs). - These
are special corners within the labor room at all facilities (PHC, CHC, DH) where deliveries occur.
Services include resuscitation, provision of warmth, prevention of infections, and early Initiation of
breastfeeding. ? Program driver. - Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram that entitles the mother and
infants to free delivery, medicines/ blood, diet, pick up and drop in government facilities

questions.text:
Lesion of dominant parietal lobe causes which of the following? 
1. Dysphasia 
2. Acalculia 
3. Dyslexia 
4. Contralateral neglect 
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: Features of localized cerebral lesions: 1.
Frontallobe Functions—Personality, emotional response, social behavior, contralateral motor control,
language, micturition Lesions—Disinhibition, lack of initiative, antisocial behavior, impaired memory,
urinary incontinence, grasp reflexes, anosmia, expressive dysphasia, contralateral hemiparesis or
monoparesis, frontal release sign, Seizures often nocturnal with motor activity, versive head
movements. 2. Temporal lobe ? Dominant side Auditory perception, speech, language, verbal
memory, smell Balance Lesions - Dysphasia, Receptive aphasia,dyslexia, poor verbal
memory,homonymous hemianopia, Contralateral homonymous upper quadrantanopia (davidson)
Complex hallucinations (smell, sound, vision, memory), ? Nondominant side Functions - Auditory
perception, music, tone sequences,Melody/pitch zperception,Non-verbal memory,Smell,Balance
Lesion - Poor nonverbal memory, loss of musical skills, complexed hallucination, homonymous
hemianopia, confusional states failure to recognize faces Contralateral homonymous upper
quadrantanopia(Davidson) 3. Parietal lobe ? Dominant side Function - Calculation, language, planned
movement, appreciation of size, shape, weight, and texture Lesion - Acalculia Dysphasia (Spoken
language), dyslexia (reading), apraxia, agnosia, homonymous hemianopia, Contralateral hemisensory
loss Astereognosis, Agraphaesthesia Contralateral homonymous lower quadrantanopia (devidson)
Asymmetry of optokinetic nystagmus (OKN), focal sensory losss ? Nondominant side Function -
Spatial orientation, constructional skills Lesions - Neglect of nondominant side, spatial disorientation,
constructional apraxia, dressing apraxia, homonymous hemianopia Contralateral hemisensory loss,
Astereognosis, Agraphaesthesia, Contralateral homonymous, lower quadrantanopia (davidson),
Asymmetry of OKN, Focal sensory losss 4. Occipital lobe Functions— Visual processing
Lesions—Visual inattention, visual loss, visual agnosia, homonymous hernianopia (macular sparing),
Simple visual hallucinations (e.g. phosphenes, zigzag lines) Lesions of anterior speech area (Broca's,
posterior part of inferior frontal gyrus)—expressive dysphasia. Damage of temporoparietal region
(Wernicke's). Causes—receptive dysphasia
